full_text: In this demonstration, I'll show how BillingCenter processes automatic disbursements. We will continue to use the Snyder & Associates account that we used in the previous demo. The financials pie chart is green, indicating the policy is already paid in full. Let's suppose there is a midterm policy change that results in a reduction in premium. The excess money from the reduction in premium will be automatically dispersed to the policyholder. First, I'll switch to Superuser to advance the clock by a month. I click the Internal Tools tab. Now I click Testing System Clock in the sidebar. I click the Add Month button to advance the clock. The clock has been successfully changed. Let's return to BillingCenter. Now, let's go to the policy. From here, I click the Actions menu button to open the Policy Change Wizard. I select Change Policy from the menu. The effective date looks fine and no special handling is required. I'll move to Step 2. I click Add to create a policy change billing instruction. The premium reduction is for $200. So I type negative $200 in the Amount field. I click Finish. The total field shows the negative amount in red. I click Finish again to complete the action. On the policy summary, we can see the policy has $200 in designated unapplied. Let's see what happens when the automatic disbursement batch process runs. I'll switch to Superuser to run the batch process. I click the Server Tools tab. I can see automatic disbursement in the list of batch processes. I click Run. Let's return to the Jeff Park browser to view the result. First, I click a link in the sidebar to refresh the browser. I click the Summary link to return to the policy summary. I can see the $200 amount remains in designated unapplied, so it has not been disbursed yet. Let's look at the disbursement. Disbursements are listed on the Account tab, so I click the Account link on the Info Bar. Now I click the Disbursements link. The $200 disbursement is listed, and has an approved status. But there is no entry for date paid. This means the disbursement has not been issued yet. In the Details area, I notice the date due is 2 days from now. The billing plan associated with the account controls various aspects of disbursement handling such as the number of days between the disbursement date and the due date. We'll discuss disbursement options later in the lesson. Meanwhile, I'll switch to Superuser to create the disbursement. I'll go to Internal Tools to advance the clock to the due date of the disbursement. I select Testing System Clock from the menu. I'll add 2 days to the testing system clock. The due date for the disbursement is September 6. To complete the change, I click Change Date. Now I'll run a batch process to send the disbursement. Here's the disbursement batch process at the bottom of the screen. I click Run. Let's take a look at the Account Summary screen. I notice Total Unapplied is now empty. The disbursement has been issued to the policyholder. This concludes our demonstration on automatic disbursements.

segments.text: In this demonstration, I'll show how BillingCenter processes automatic disbursements. We will continue to use the Snyder & Associates account that we used in the previous demo.

The financials pie chart is green, indicating the policy is already paid in full. Let's suppose there is a midterm policy change that results in a reduction in premium. The excess money from the reduction in premium will be automatically dispersed to the policyholder.
First, I'll switch to Superuser to advance the clock by a month. I click the Internal Tools tab.
Now I click Testing System Clock in the sidebar. I click the Add Month button to advance the clock. The clock has been successfully changed. Let's return to BillingCenter.
Now, let's go to the policy. From here, I click the Actions menu button to open the Policy Change Wizard.
I select Change Policy from the menu. The effective date looks fine and no special handling is required. I'll move to Step 2.
I click Add to create a policy change billing instruction. The premium reduction is for $200.
So I type negative $200 in the Amount field. I click Finish. The total field shows the negative amount in red. I click Finish again to complete the action.
On the policy summary, we can see the policy has $200 in designated unapplied. Let's see what happens when the automatic disbursement batch process runs.
I'll switch to Superuser to run the batch process. I click the Server Tools tab.
I can see automatic disbursement in the list of batch processes. I click Run.
Let's return to the Jeff Park browser to view the result. First, I click a link in the sidebar to refresh the browser.
I click the Summary link to return to the policy summary.
I can see the $200 amount remains in designated unapplied, so it has not been disbursed yet.
Let's look at the disbursement. Disbursements are listed on the Account tab, so I click the Account link on the Info Bar.
Now I click the Disbursements link.
The $200 disbursement is listed, and has an approved status. But there is no entry for date paid. This means the disbursement has not been issued yet.
In the Details area, I notice the date due is 2 days from now.
The billing plan associated with the account controls various aspects of disbursement handling such as the number of days between the disbursement date and the due date.
We'll discuss disbursement options later in the lesson.
Meanwhile, I'll switch to Superuser to create the disbursement.
I'll go to Internal Tools to advance the clock to the due date of the disbursement.
I select Testing System Clock from the menu.
I'll add 2 days to the testing system clock.
The due date for the disbursement is September 6.
To complete the change, I click Change Date.
Now I'll run a batch process to send the disbursement.
Here's the disbursement batch process at the bottom of the screen.
I click Run.
Let's take a look at the Account Summary screen.
I notice Total Unapplied is now empty.
The disbursement has been issued to the policyholder.
This concludes our demonstration on automatic disbursements.
